snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Cassini is in the process of executing 22 daring ‘Grand Finale’ dives in the 1,200-mile gap between Saturn and its innermost ring, concluding with an epic final plunge into the gas giant’s upper atmosphere.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Cassini's Grand Finale

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

The Perseid meteor shower will peak on August 11, 12, and 13, and a Total Solar Eclipse will be visible in the United States from coast to coast on August 21.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: August 2017: A Big Month for Astronomy

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

NASA is hunting for Near-Earth Objects, while also working on ways to defend Earth against them.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Hunt for Asteroids

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

NASA's OMG and Operation IceBridge missions are investigating the thinning of Greenland's ice sheets from both above and below.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Greenland's Thinning Ice

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

NASA studies are looking at the effects of space travel on the human body's immune system.

Functional Immune Story: https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/research/news/functional_immune
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Your Immune System... In Space

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Sounding rocket missions can often be the key to getting a quick answer to a tightly focused science question.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: NASA's Sounding Rockets

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

In 2017 and 2018, three comets will pass near the Earth providing the opportunity to observe and study these icy interlopers.

4*P Morphology Campaign: http://www.psi.edu/41P45P46P
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Close Approach Comets

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Stringent testing is underway to prove the James Webb Space Telescope can handle an Earth-shaking take-off and still capture the universe’s first light while deeply ensconced in the hyper-cold of space.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Readying the Webb Telescope for Launch

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

We once thought oceans made our planet unique, but we’re now coming to realize that ‘ocean worlds’ are all around us.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Ocean Worlds

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Stop what you’re doing and mark your calendar. Jupiter can be viewed at opposition from sunset on April 7, 2017 to sunrise on April 8, 2017.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: An All-Nighter with Planet Jupiter

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

NASA is embracing small satellite designs, from tiny CubeSats to micro-satellites. These miniature marvels are providing many ways to collect science data and to demonstrate new technologies.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: NASA Embraces Small Satellites

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

NASA has launched an ozone sensor to help monitor long-term change in the ozone layer. This sensor, called SAGE III, will be installed on the International Space Station in 2017.

http://www.nasa.gov/station
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Earth Observation from the Station

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

On Sunday, February 26th, the moon will pass in front of the sun, transforming rays of sunlight across parts of South America, southern Africa and Antarctica into fat crescents and thin rings of light.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Southern Hemisphere Solar Eclipse

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

We’re over 230 episodes in! Which were your favorites? From our home planet to discovering new worlds, find out.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Milestones In Review

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Earth will pass through a stream of debris from comet 2003 EH1 on January 3, 2017, producing a shower of meteors known as the Quadrantids.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: New Year's Fireworks from a Shattered Comet

snippet.description:
NASA Science: http://science.nasa.gov/
International Space Station: http://www.nasa.gov/station

A new NASA study is investigating how different light spectra can be used to effect astronauts' sleep, or lack of sleep.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Power of Light

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Observations by NASA's IRIS spacecraft suggest that "heat bombs" are going off in the sun's outer atmosphere, helping to explain why the solar corona is so mysteriously hot.

https://iris.gsfc.nasa.gov/
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Mystery of Coronal Heating

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Nothing beats a bright and beautiful "supermoon." Except maybe, three supermoons! 2016 ends with a trio of full moons at their closest points to Earth.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: 2016 Ends with Three Supermoons

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

30 million years from now, a massive cloud of gas will collide with the Milky Way. Astronomers are studying the incoming cloud and learning more about its origin.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Massive Cloud on Collision Course with the Milky Way

snippet.description:
MMS: http://www.nasa.gov/mms

Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more

Four NASA spacecraft have performed a thrilling maneuver to understand the physics of explosive reconnection in Earth's magnetosphere.

Read this story: https://science.nasa.gov/news-articles/nasa-spacecraft-fly-record-setting-formation
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: NASA Spacecraft Fly in Record-setting Formation

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Venus and Jupiter are converging for a spectacular conjunction in the sunset sky on August 27th
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: A Spectacular Conjunction of Venus and Jupiter

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Summer is the season for electric-blue noctilucent clouds. NASA's AIM spacecraft is finding that these clouds continue to reveal details about how the atmosphere works.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Electric Blue Sunsets

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Researchers using NASA's Kepler space telescope have found evidence of strong magnetic fields in the cores of stars--a finding that could upset theories of stellar evolution.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Strong Magnetic Fields Found Inside Stars

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

NASA is sniffing out the sweet smell of methane on Earth, Mars and beyond. It's a greenhouse gas and, in some places, possibly a sign of ancient life.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Methane Stinks? On Earth, Mars, and Beyond

snippet.description:
http://science.nasa.gov/
Visit http://www.nasa.gov/station for more from the ISS

As hurricane season unfolds, a helpful set of eyes mounted on the International Space Station allows scientists to observe massive storms from a special angle.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: A New Angle on Global Wind Measurements

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Earth's oceans could be concealing a mystery about climate change. Researchers have recently found evidence of hidden heat hundreds of meters below the ocean's surface.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Reshuffling Heat on a Warming Planet

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

A global effort to monitor air quality is in the works as the US, Korea, and the European Union prepare to launch geostationary satellites capable of monitoring pollutants and other aerosols.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Monitoring Air Quality

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Dynamic bubbles of ionization in Earth's upper atmosphere can cause GPS signals to "twinkle" like stars, affecting the quality of navigation on Earth below. NASA recently conducted a mission called CINDI to investigate this phenomenon.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Twinkle Twinkle GPS

snippet.description:
http://science.nasa.gov/
More from the ISS: http://www.nasa.gov/station

For the first time, researchers have identified a genetic marker associated with a spaceflight medical issue. It is in the enzymes associated with the "1 carbon pathway."
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: One Carbon Metabolism on the Space Station

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Mars and Saturn are getting together in the constellation Scorpius for back-to-back oppositions in May and June 2016.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Red and Golden Planets at Opposition

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

On May 9th, Mercury will move across the face of the sun, offering a rare viewing opportunity for professional astronomers and backyard sky watchers alike.

2016 Mercury Transit: http://mercurytransit.gsfc.nasa.gov
Solar Dynamics Observatory: http://sdo.gsfc.nasa.gov/
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The 2016 Transit of Mercury (updated)

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Assembly of NASA's next great space observatory, the James Webb Space Telescope, is underway. It will show researchers the first stars and galaxies that formed in the early universe.

JWST WebbCam: http://www.jwst.nasa.gov/webcam.html

Explore JWST: http://www.jwst.nasa.gov/
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: NASA's Next Great Space Telescope

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Researchers using a Japanese X-ray satellite with NASA participation have found the chemical ingredients of Earth-like planets in the Virgo cluster of galaxies.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Special Ingredients... of Earth

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

When the Space Age began, explorers were eager to visit the planets of the solar system. As the years have passed, however, astronomers have realized that the moons of the solar system may be even more interesting.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Amazing Moons

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

During the early hours of March 9, 2016 the new moon will pass directly in front of the sun, producing a total eclipse of the sun over South East Asia.

A partial eclipse will be viewable the evening of March 8, 2016 in western-most parts of the USA including Alaska and Hawai'i.

More from NASA about eclipses! http://www.nasa.gov/eclipse
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Indonesian Solar Eclipse

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

On March 8th, 2016 Earth and Jupiter will have a close encounter. The giant planet will be "up all night," soaring almost overhead at midnight and not setting until the sky brightens with the twilight hues of sunrise on March 9th. In July, the Juno mission will give us an even closer look.

More about Juno: www.nasa.gov/juno
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Close Encounters with Jupiter

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

About three quarters of ISS astronauts experience changes in the structure and function of their eyes.  An experiment on the space station called the “Fluid Shifts Study” is investigating these vision problems in space.

http://www.nasa.gov/station
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Horn-rims and Funny Stockings on the Space Station

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Deep in the heart of California’s Owens Valley, a strange-looking telescope stands in the desert landscape listening for echos of distant stars.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Listening to the Stars

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

The Jason-3 satellite, launched on January 17, 2016, is allowing scientists to continue a 23-year record of crucial ocean monitoring.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Measuring the Rising Seas

snippet.description:
As 2015 comes to a close, tell us which ScienceCast you've learned the most from! What do you want to see in 2016?

Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Researchers have used NASA space telescopes to prove that space-time is much less "foamy" than some models predict.  Understanding their result requires a trip into the world of quantum physics.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Quantum Foam

snippet.description:
ScienceCasts has passed 200 episodes! Tell us in the comments which has been your favorite!

Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

NASA supported researchers are working on Synthetic Muscles that could be used to create humanoid robots for space exploration.

http://www.nasa.gov/station
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Synthetic Muscles

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Earth is surrounded by electrons that can be disruptive to our technology. NASA is using high-altitude balloons and spacecraft to monitor and understand these particles in the radiation belts surrounding our planet.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Escape of the Destructive Electrons

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

A new NASA-funded tool is taking some of the ‘wild’ out of wildfires by making it possible for U.S. fire managers to better spot dangerous blazes.

Active fire maps of the United States: http://activefiremaps.fs.fed.us
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Taking the Wild out of Wildfire

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Astronomers have long hoped to find another planet in the cosmos similar to Earth--a blue dot in the distance that could harbor life akin to our own. NASA's Kepler spacecraft may have found the next best thing.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: In Search of Earth... 2.0

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

During an unprecedented 1-year mission to the International Space Station, scientists are studying how astronauts' bodies respond to long-duration space travel.

http://www.nasa.gov/station
https://www.nasa.gov/1ym
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The "Omics" of Space Travel

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

The Fine Motor Skills experiment on the station is looking at how long-duration microgravity effects fine motor task performance.

www.nasa.gov/station
http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/research/experiments/1767.html
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Using a Tablet Computer in Space

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

NASA's Cassini Spacecraft is about to make a daring plunge through one of the plumes emerging from Saturn's moon Enceladus.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Close Encounter with Enceladus

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Look east before sunrise in late October for a beautiful conjunction of bright planets.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Dawn Triangle of Planets

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

The ESA/NASA Solar and Heliospheric Observatory has discovered more than 3000 doomed comets that have passed close to the sun.

Sungrazer Project: http://sungrazer.nrl.navy.mil
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Spacecraft Discovers Thousands of Doomed Comets

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Astronomers using NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope have discovered an immense cloud of hydrogen evaporating from a Neptune-sized planet named GJ 436b. The planet’s atmosphere is evaporating because of extreme irradiation from its parent star.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Worlds within Worlds

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

NASA-supported researchers have found that ice covering Greenland is melting faster than previously thought. The action is happening out of sight, below the surface.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Hidden Meltdown of Greenland

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

This week, Earth passes through a stream of debris from Comet Swift-Tuttle, source of the annual Perseid meteor shower. Forecasters say the show could be especially good this year because the Moon is nearly new when the shower peaks on Aug. 12-13.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: A Good Year for Perseid Meteors

snippet.description:
For updates from the International Space Station go to http://www.nasa.gov/station

Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Advances in the understanding of how fluids behave in low gravity is key to spacecraft operations. A long-awaited spin-off is an excellent cup of coffee in space.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Space Coffee

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

With support from NASA, the EPA has developed an app to track algae that can threaten fresh water supplies.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Good, the Bad, and the Algae

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Venus and Jupiter are converging for a must-see close encounter at the end of June. It could be the best backyard sky show of 2015.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Amazing Sunset Sky Show

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

On Earth, a fast runner takes a few hours to complete a marathon. On Mars, it's taken 11 years. NASA's Opportunity rover crossed that finish line in 2015.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The First Martian Marathon

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

The Amazon rainforest and the Sahara desert seem utterly different. Yet NASA satellites have discovered a surprising connection that intimately links these two disparate parts of our planet.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Desert Dust Feeds Amazon Forests

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

At the end of a day devoted to Earth, people can look to the heavens for a beautiful shower of Lyrid meteors.

http://www.nasa.gov/content/earth-right-now/
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Earth Day Meteor Shower

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Citizen scientists scanning images from a NASA observatory have found "yellow balls" in space that may hold important clues to the mysteries of starbirth.

Spitzer Space Telescope: http://www.spitzer.caltech.edu/
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Citizen Scientists Discover Yellow Balls in Space

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

On Saturday morning, April 4th, sky watchers in the USA can see a brief but beautiful total eclipse of the Moon.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Total Eclipse of the Moon

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Tiny solar flares on the sun may be having an outsized effect on the temperature of the sun's atmosphere. To investigate, scientists will observe these "nanoflares" using a space telescope built for black holes.

NuSTAR Mission Site: http://www.nustar.caltech.edu/
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Mystery of Nanoflares

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

NASA is about to launch a fleet of spacecraft to investigate the mystery of "magnetic reconnection," which is making things explode across the cosmos.

MMS Page: http://www.nasa.gov/mms/
MMS Blog: http://blogs.nasa.gov/mms/
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Studying Earth’s Magnetic Personality

snippet.description:
This video has been updated! Please visit http://youtu.be/h6O6hSugZvw for the updated version.

Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

The key to unraveling the mysterious cause of Alzheimer's disease may not lie in the recesses of the human brain, but rather in the weightless expanses of outer space.

SABOL Experiment Details:
http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/research/experiments/1374.html
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Subtracting Gravity from Alzheimer's

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

NASA has launched SMAP, a new satellite to study water, not in oceans or lakes but in the soil beneath our feet. This often overlooked repository of water can have big effects on weather, climate, drought and agriculture.

http://smap.jpl.nasa.gov/
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Mud Matters

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Researchers are using a pair of robots to examine the strange way fluids slosh and bubble on the International Space Station

http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/research/experiments/980.html
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Strange Way Fluids Slosh on the International Space Station

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Check out NASA's Geminid Meteor Shower page! http://www.nasa.gov/connect/chat/geminids_2014.html

Earth is passing through a stream of debris from "rock comet" 3200 Phaethon, source of the annual Geminid meteor shower. Forecasters expect as many as 120 meteors per hour when the shower peaks on Dec. 13-14.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Embers from a Rock Comet: The 2014 Geminid Meteor Shower

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Arctic and Antarctic sea ice are both affected by climate change, but the two poles of Earth are behaving in intriguingly different ways.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Climate Change and the Yin-Yang of Polar Sea Ice

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

The Moon might not be as dead as it looks. Researchers using NASA's Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter have found signs of geologically-recent volcanic eruptions on Earth's natural satellite.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Young Volcanoes on the Moon

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

The European Space Agency's Rosetta spacecraft is about to attempt something "ridiculously difficult" - landing a probe on the surface of a speeding comet.

JPL Rosetta Mission Site - http://rosetta.jpl.nasa.gov/
ESA/Rosetta Mission Site - http://rosetta.esa.int

Try your hand at landing a spacecraft on a comet with NASA Space Place's Comet Quest!: http://spaceplace.nasa.gov/comet-quest/
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: How to Land on a Comet

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

On October 23rd, the Moon will pass in front of the sun, off-center, producing a partial solar eclipse visible in most of the United States.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Sunset Solar Eclipse

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

As climate change continues to hammer Arctic sea ice, pushing back its summertime boundaries to record-high latitudes, NASA is flying an innovative airborne mission to find out how these developments will affect worldwide weather.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Cloudy Future of Arctic Sea Ice

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

NASA's MAVEN spacecraft has reached Mars and it is beaming back "First Light" images of the Red Planet's upper atmosphere. The data could help researchers understand what transformed Mars from a hospitable planet billions of years ago into a desiccated wasteland today.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: First Light for MAVEN

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

The weekend launch of ISS-RapidScat onboard SpaceX-4 has kickstarted a new era for the International Space Station as a giant Earth-observing satellite.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: A Giant Among Earth Satellites

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Mark your calendar: On Oct. 8th, the Moon will pass through the shadow of Earth for a total lunar eclipse. Sky watchers in the USA will see the Moon turn a beautiful shade of celestial red and maybe turquoise, too.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: A Colorful Lunar Eclipse

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Astronauts onboard the International Space Station report seeing flames that behave like jellyfish. Video of the microgravity phenomenon is a must-see.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Jellyfish Flame on the International Space Station

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Almost 30 years after the Montreal Protocol put the brakes on ozone-depleting chemicals, one compound remains stubbornly and mysteriously abundant in the atmosphere. NASA scientists are tracking down the source and studying its effect on the ozone layer.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Mystery in the Ozone Layer

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

A NASA sounding rocket has confirmed that the solar system is inside an ancient supernova remnant. Life on Earth survived despite the nearby blasts.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Evidence for Supernovas Near Earth

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Astronomers are not only discovering planets around distant suns, they are also starting to measure those worlds with astonishing precision. The diameter of a super-Earth named Kepler-93b is now known to within an accuracy of 148 miles.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Sizing up an Exoplanet

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Wake up early in mid-August to see Venus and Jupiter shining side-by-side.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Beautiful Conjunction

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Comet Siding Spring is about to fly historically close to Mars. The encounter could spark Martian auroras, a meteor shower, and other unpredictable effects. Whatever happens, NASA's fleet of Mars satellites will have a ringside seat.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Colliding Atmospheres - Mars vs Comet Siding Spring

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Which is brighter--a flurry of Perseid fireballs or a supermoon? Sky watchers will find out this August when the biggest and brightest full Moon of 2014 arrives just in time for the peak of the annual Perseid meteor shower.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Perseid Meteors vs the Supermoon

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

A mysterious X-ray signal from the Perseus cluster of galaxies, which researchers say cannot be explained by known physics, could be a key clue to the nature of Dark Matter.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Big Mystery in the Perseus Cluster

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

NASA's New Horizons spacecraft is only a year away from Pluto. Researchers are buzzing with anticipation as NASA prepares to encounter a new world for the first time in decades.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: One Year to Pluto

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

The summer of 2014 will be bathed in moonlight as three perigee "supermoons" occur in consecutive months: July, August, September.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: A Summer of Super Moons

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

A new species is about to join astronauts on the International Space Station: Drosophila melanogaster, also known as the "fruit fly." Genetically speaking, the bug-eyed insects have a lot in common with human beings, and they are poised to teach researchers a great deal about voyaging into deep space.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Fruit Flies on the International Space Station

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

NASA is about to launch a satellite dedicated to the study of the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide. The Orbiting Carbon Observatory (OCO-2) will quantify global CO2 sources and sinks, and help researchers predict the future of climate change.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: NASA to Launch Carbon Observatory

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

In early June, a laser beam lanced out of the night sky over California, heralding a breakthrough in space communications. The message it carried was "Hello, World."
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: A Laser Message from Space: "Hello World"

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

NASA and NOAA agree: Solar Max has arrived, but this "mini Max" is not like any other solar maximum of the Space Age.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Solar Mini-Max

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

Later this year, Europe's Rosetta probe will orbit and land on comet 67P/Churyumov--Gerasimenko. New images of the comet show that it will be a lively place when Rosetta arrives.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Rosetta Comet Comes Alive

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

A new map of the galaxy by ESA's Planck spacecraft has revealed gigantic loops of magnetism and other structures that point to a magnetic dynamo at work in the Milky Way.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Milky Way is Not Just a Refrigerator Magnet

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

The Jason-2 satellite sees something brewing in the Pacific. Researchers say it could be a significant El Niño with implications for global weather and climate.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: El Niño - Is 2014 the New 1997?

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2014/12may_noturningback/ for more.

A new study led by NASA researchers shows that half-a-dozen key glaciers in the West Antarctic Ice Sheet are in irreversible decline. The melting of these sprawling icy giants will affect global sea levels in the centuries ahead.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: No Turning Back - West Antarctic Glaciers in Irreversible Decline

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2014/06may_newshower/ for more.

Sky watchers in North America could witness a new meteor shower on May 24th when, for the first time, Earth passes through a cloud of dust from periodic comet 209P/LINEAR.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: NASA on the Lookout for a New Meteor Shower

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2014/02may_superstorm/ for more.

Two years ago, an intense solar storm narrowly missed Earth. If it had hit, researchers say, we could still be picking up the pieces.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Carrington-class CME Narrowly Misses Earth

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2014/25apr_lettuce/ for more.

A new life form is taking root on the International Space Station, and its name is "Outregeous." The space-faring lettuce was delivered to the space station by a SpaceX Dragon capsule on April 20th.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Lettuce Orbit Earth -- A New Form of Life Takes Root on the ISS

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2014/16apr_teleconnections/ for more.

NASA's AIM spacecraft is discovering unexpected "teleconnections" in Earth's atmosphere that link weather and climate across vast distances.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Unexpected Teleconnections in Noctilucent Clouds

snippet.description: Please visit https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7d3t1_l4bcw for an updated version of this video
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Unexpected Teleconnections in Noctilucent Clouds (update available)

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2014/10apr_twins/ for more.

Next year, with the assistance of the world's only twin astronauts, NASA will conduct an unprecedented experiment in human biology. While one twin remains on the ground, the other will circle Earth onboard the International Space Station for a full year. Will the twins still be identical when they are re-united? The answer could help NASA make space travel safer for generations of astronauts to come.

Proposals Selection: http://www.nasa.gov/content/nasa-selects-10-proposals-to-explore-genetic-aspects-of-spaceflight/#.U0Lyga1dW7Z
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Separated at Launch

snippet.description:
Earth and Mars are converging for a close encounter in April, an event astronomers call "the opposition of Mars."

Credit: NASA
snippet.title: ScienceCast - The Opposition of Mars - HD

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2014/27mar_tetrad/ for more.

A total lunar eclipse on April 15th marks the beginning of a remarkable series of eclipses all visible from North America.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: A Tetrad of Lunar Eclipses

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2014/07mar_frontierfields/ for more.

Astronomers have figured out how to use the gravity of distant galaxies to bend light and magnify images, allowing them to see deeper into the cosmos than ever before.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: A Telescope Bigger than a Galaxy

snippet.description:
Details can be found at http://planetquest.jpl.nasa.gov/

Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2014/26feb_multiplication/ for more.

Today, NASA announced a breakthrough addition to the catalog of new planets. Researchers using Kepler have confirmed 715 new worlds, almost quadrupling the number of planets previously confirmed by the planet-hunting spacecraft. Some of the new worlds are similar in size to Earth and orbit in the habitable zone of their parent stars.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: A Sudden Multiplication of Planets

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2014/26feb_gpm/ for more.

NASA and JAXA are about to launch a new satellite that can see through storms, tracking rain and snow around the globe better than any previous observatory. The Global Precipitation Measurement Core Observatory is scheduled to lift off from Japan on Feb. 27th.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Follow the Water

snippet.description:
Visit http://www.nasa.gov/iss-science to learn about science on the station

and http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2014/14feb_10years/ for more.

With the space station no longer "under construction," the world's most advanced orbital laboratory is open for business. The station has just received a 10-year extension from NASA, giving researchers the time they need to take full advantage of its unique capabilities.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: 10 More Years

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2014/07feb_drought/ for more.

California is experiencing a historic drought--by some measures the deepest in more than 100 years. NASA researchers are investigating a number of explanations for what the underlying cause may be.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: California Drought

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2014/30jan_coldspot/ for more.

NASA researchers plan to create the coldest spot in the known Universe--inside the International Space Station. The device, known as the Cold Atom Lab, could discover new forms of matter and novel quantum phenomena.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Coolest Spot in the Universe

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.

The New Year started off with a bang when a small asteroid hit Earth. Infrasound records indicate that the space rock exploded in the atmosphere over the Atlantic Ocean like 500 tons of TNT.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: New Year's Asteroid Strike

snippet.description: This video has been updated. Please view the update at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eMaPAM3vfv0
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Countdown to Pluto

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2014/10jan_firewater/ for more.

Astronauts on the ISS are experimenting with a form of water that has a strange property: it can help start fire. This fundamental physics investigation could have down-to-Earth benefits such as clean-burning municipal waste disposal and improved saltwater purification.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Starting Fire in Water

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2013/23dec_antarctica/ for more.

A vast bank of electric-blue clouds has appeared over Antarctica, signaling the start of the season for southern hemisphere noctilucent clouds.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Electric-Blue Clouds Appear Over Antarctica

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2013/27nov_rockcomet/ for more!

"Rock Comet" 3200 Phaethon has sprouted a tail, proving that the mysterious object is the source of the annual Geminid meteor shower.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Rock Comet Sprouts a Tail

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2013/27nov_genius/ for more!

Researchers working with magnetic fluids on the International Space Station are taking "smart materials" to the next level. With proper coaxing, molecules can assemble themselves into "genius materials" with surprising properties. This is opening a new frontier in material science.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Genius Materials on the ISS

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2013/15nov_twocomets/ for more!

Consider it a cosmic coincidence: On Nov. 18-19, two comets (ISON and Encke) are going to fly by the planet Mercury in quick succession. NASA's MESSENGER spacecraft will have a front-row seat for the rare double flyby.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Two Comets to Fly By Mercury on Nov 18 & 19

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2013/12nov_maven/ for more!

Mars was once on track to become a thriving Earth-like planet, yet today it is an apparently lifeless wasteland. A NASA spacecraft named MAVEN will soon journey to Mars to find out what went wrong on the Red Planet.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: What Happened to Mars? A Planetary Mystery

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2013/01nov_ismsounds/ for more!

As Voyager 1 recedes from the solar system, researchers are listening for "interstellar music" (a.k.a. plasma waves) to learn more about conditions outside the heliosphere.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Sounds of Interstellar Space

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2013/01nov_ismsounds/ for more!

As Voyager 1 recedes from the solar system, researchers are listening for "interstellar music" (a.k.a. plasma waves) to learn more about conditions outside the heliosphere.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Sounds of Interstellar Space

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2013/25oct_aviationswx/ for more!

Astronauts aren't the only ones who need to worry about solar flares. Ordinary air travelers can also be exposed to significant doses of radiation during solar storms. A new computer model developed by NASA aims to help protect the public by predicting space weather hazards to aviation.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Effects of Space Weather on Aviation

snippet.description:
For more, visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2013/24sep_ison2/

To learn how you can help, visit isoncampaign.org

Comet ISON is still more than two months away from its spectacular close encounter with the sun. Already, the brightening comet has become a good target for backyard telescopes in the pre-dawn sky.

Amateur Astronomer Image Credits:

0:11 - Nirmal Paul, Canary Island, Teide, 09/16/2013
0:31 - Nick Howes & Ernesto Guido, Liverpool Telescope, 05/02/2013
(Credited as an annotation. Apologies for the original credit omission)
0:37 - Knut Schaeffner, Verclause, France, 09/14/2013
0:48 - Theodoros Giaourtsis, Vrastama Halkidikis, Greece, 09/08/2013
0:54 - Pete Lawrence, Selsey UK, 09/15/2013
1:06 - Efrain Morales Rivera, Aguadilla, Puerto Rico, 09/15/2013
1:25 - Christina, SLOOHs Robotic Observatory, Canary Islands, 08/29/2013
2:08 - Waldemar, Skorupa, Provence France, 09/05/2013
3:02 - Rolando Ligustri, Talmassons (UD) IT, MPC235, 09/07/2013
3:14 - Maximilian Teodorescu, Dumitrana (Ilfov), Romania, 09/07/2013
3:38 - Roy and Jodi McCullough, Salem, Ohio, 09/04/2013
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Amateur Astronomers See Comet ISON Approaching the Sun

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for breaking science news.

The full Moon closest to the northern autumnal equinox is coming this week. Don't miss the Harvest Moon.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Harvest Moon

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for breaking science news.

Sometimes, Earth mimics a supernova, producing a Terrestrial Gamma-ray Flash from the tops of thunderstorms. A new lightning sensor on the International Space Station could solve the mystery of these energetic bursts.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: ISS "Firestation" to Explore the Tops of Thunderstorms

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for breaking science news.

A NASA spacecraft slated for launch in September will fly to the Moon to investigate the tenuous lunar atmosphere. Researchers hope "LADEE" will solve a mystery that has been puzzling them since the days of Apollo.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: NASA Mission Seeks Lunar Air

snippet.description: Comet ISON is heading for a Thanksgiving Day brush with the sun, but first it's going to pay a visit to Mars. In this week's ScienceCast, researchers discuss what might happen when Comet ISON meets the Red Planet.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Comet ISON to Fly By Mars

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for breaking science news.

An exotic class of exoplanets called "hot Jupiters" are even weirder than astronomers imagined. While these worlds may have Earth-like blue skies, new data show that they are anything but Earth-like.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Strange Attraction of Hot Jupiters

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2013/05aug_fieldflip/ for more!

Something big is happening on the sun. The sun's global magnetic field is about to flip, a sign that Solar Max has arrived.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Sun's Magnetic Field is About to Flip

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for breaking science news.

New research from NASA's Meteoroid Environment Office identifies the Perseids as the "fireball champion" of annual meteor showers. This year's Perseid display peaks on August 12th and 13th.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Perseid Fireballs

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for breaking science news.

Saturn's giant moon Titan is dotted with hydrocarbon lakes and seas that bear an uncanny resemblance to bodies of water on Earth. Strangely, though, Titan's lakes and seas have no waves.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Mystery of the Missing Waves on Titan

snippet.description:
Read http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2013/15jul_coffeecup/ for more!

Drinking coffee in space is surprisingly tricky. Physicists researching the strange behavior of fluids onboard the International Space Station have invented a zero-g coffee cup to make the morning "cuppa Joe" a little easier to swallow.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Zero Gravity Coffee Cup

snippet.description:
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2013/01jul_oppy/ for more

When Opportunity left Earth in 2003, many observers expected the rover to survive no more than a few months on the hostile surface of Mars. 10 years later, Opportunity is still going strong and could be poised to make its biggest discoveries yet at a place named Solander Point.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Opportunity's Improbable Anniversary

snippet.description: Arctic permafrost soils contain more accumulated carbon than all the human fossil-fuel emissions since 1850 combined. Warming Arctic permafrost, poised to release its own gases into the atmosphere, could be the "sleeping giant" of climate change.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Arctic Permafrost

snippet.description: Researchers experimenting with flames onboard the International Space Station have produced a strange, cool-burning form of fire that could help improve the efficiency of auto engines.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Strange Flames on the International Space Station

snippet.description: Glowing electric-blue at the edge of space, noctilucent clouds have surprised researchers by appearing early this year. The unexpected apparition hints at a change in the "teleconnections" of Earth's atmosphere.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: An Early Start for Noctilucent Clouds

snippet.description: NASA is tracking a large near-Earth asteroid as it passes by the Earth-Moon system on May 31st. Amateur astronomers in the northern hemisphere may be able to see the space rock for themselves during the 1st week of June.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Big Asteroid Flyby

snippet.description: Astronomers using NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope are making weather maps of an exotic class of exoplanets called "hot Jupiters." What they're finding is wilder than anything we experience here in our own solar system.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Big Weather on Hot Jupiters

snippet.description: NASA researchers who monitor the Moon for meteoroid impacts have detected the brightest explosion in the history of their program.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Bright Explosion on the Moon

snippet.description: The three brightest planets in this month's night sky are lining up for a beautiful sunset conjunction at the end of May.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Sunset Triangle

snippet.description: Can plants adapt to the novelty of climate change? Researchers seeking to answer this question have sent genetically engineered plants to the ISS for exposure to extreme conditions. To report their condition, the plants have learned to glow in the dark.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Glow-in-the-Dark Plants on the ISS

snippet.description: Saturn and Earth are lining up for a beautiful view of the ringed planet. Saturn will be at its best and brightest on April 28th.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Saturn Close Up

snippet.description: Sungrazing Comet ISON, expected to become a bright naked-eye object later this year, might dust the Earth with meteoroids in early 2014. Researchers discuss the possibilities in this week's ScienceCast.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Comet ISON Meteor Shower

snippet.description:
An advanced particle detector onboard the International Space Station may have recorded its first whiff of Dark Matter. Researchers are excited about the possibility of finally understanding what this mysterious substance is made of.

Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for breaking science news.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: A Whiff of Dark Matter on the ISS

snippet.description: Life as we know it doesn't thrive on planets without ozone layers. A new instrument slated for launch to the ISS will monitor Earth's protective ozone shell with greater depth and precision than ever before.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Don't Let This Happen to Your Planet

snippet.description: A comet is heading for Mars, and there is a chance that it might hit the Red Planet in October 2014.  An impact wouldn't necessarily mean the end of NASA's Mars program. But it would transform the program along with Mars itself.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Collision Course? A Comet Heads for Mars

snippet.description: Comet Pan-STARRS has survived its encounter with the sun and is now emerging from twilight in the sunset skies of the northern hemisphere. A NASA spacecraft monitoring the comet has beamed back pictures of a wild and ragged tail.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Sunset Comet

snippet.description: Forecasters say solar maximum is due in 2013. To prepare, the UN is organizing an international response to stormy space weather.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Stormy Space Weather

snippet.description: Something unexpected is happening on the sun. 2013 is supposed to be the year of Solar Max, but solar activity is much lower than expected. At least one leading forecaster expects the sun to rebound with a double-peaked maximum later this year.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Solar Max Double Peaked

snippet.description: Two weeks after an asteroid exploded over Russia's Ural mountains, scientists are making progress understanding the origin and make-up of the unexpected space rock. This week's ScienceCast presents their latest results.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: What Exploded Over Russia?

snippet.description:
The planet Mercury is about to make its best apparition of the year for backyard sky watchers. Look west at sunset for a piercing pink planet surrounded by twilight blue.

Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for breaking science news.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Pink Planet at Sunset

snippet.description: A comet falling in from the distant reaches of the solar system could become a naked-eye object in early March. This is Comet Pan-STARRS's first visit to the inner solar system, so surprises are possible as its virgin ices are exposed to intense solar heating.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: A Naked-Eye Comet in March 2013

snippet.description: On Feb. 15th an asteroid about half the size of a football field will fly past Earth closer than many man-made satellites. Since regular sky surveys began in the 1990s, astronomers have never seen an object so big come so close to our planet.
snippet.title: ScienceCast: Record-Setting Asteroid Flyby

snippet.description: Astronomers are keeping a close eye on a newly-discovered Comet ISON, which could become visible in broad daylight later this year when it skims through the atmosphere of the sun.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Comet of the Century

snippet.description: Researchers studying thunderstorms have made a surprising discovery: The lightning we see with our eyes has a dark competitor that discharges storm clouds and flings antimatter into space. Astrophysicists and meteorologists are scrambling to understand "dark lightning."
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Dark Lightning

snippet.description: The Moon and Jupiter are converging for a heavenly sky show on Christmas 2012. Got a telescope? Something extra-special is happening on Jupiter that makes it an appealing target for backyard optics.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Christmas Sky Show

snippet.description:
The Mayan calendar explained! The world is safe from rogue planets, solar flares and other imagined calamities!
Watch this NOW to learn why NASA Science says you'll be here Dec. 22 to view it again!

Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for breaking science news.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Why the World Didn't End Yesterday

snippet.description: The Geminid meteor shower peaks on Dec. 13th and 14th when Earth runs through a stream of debris from a strange object that some astronomers are calling a "rock comet."
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Rock Comet Meteor Shower

snippet.description: The Milky Way's supermassive black hole is generally a picky eater, but NASA's NuSTAR spacecraft recently caught it in the act of having a snack!
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Diner at the Center of the Galaxy

snippet.description: NASA has an unusual candidate for the astronaut corps--a rubber chicken. Seriously. Beloved by schoolchildren around the country, Camilla the rubber chicken has been training in fighter jets, flying to the edge of space, and visiting classrooms around the country as she prepares to go where no chicken has gone before.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: NASA's Cure for a Common Phobia

snippet.description:
Scientists and sky watchers are converging on the northeast coast of Australia, near the Great Barrier Reef, for a total eclipse of the sun.

Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Total Eclipse of the Sun

snippet.description:
Astronomers have caught a red giant star in the act of devouring one of its planets. It could be a preview of what will happen to Earth five billion years from now.
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Fried Planets

snippet.description: Soon, Earth will pass through a stream of debris from Halley's Comet, source of the annual Orionid meteor shower. Forecasters expect 25 meteors per hour when the shower peaks on Oct. 21st.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: A Meteor Shower from Halley's Comet

snippet.description: A NASA spacecraft has recorded eerie-sounding radio emissions coming from our own planet. These beautiful "songs of Earth" could, ironically, be responsible for the proliferation of deadly electrons in the Van Allen Belts.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Sound of Earthsong

snippet.description: A former rock-n-roller turned NASA engineer explains why he thinks Curiosity--both the Mars rover and the human desire to learn new things--matters to ordinary people on Earth.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Why Curiosity Matters

snippet.description: Once, astronomers thought planets couldn't form around binary stars. Now Kepler has found a whole system of planets orbiting a double star. This finding shows that planetary systems are weirder and more abundant than previously thought.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Weird Planets

snippet.description: Most spacecraft try to avoid the Van Allen Belts, two doughnut-shaped regions around Earth filled with "killer electrons." This morning NASA launched two heavily-shielded spacecraft directly into the belts. The Radiation Belt Storm Probes are on a two-year mission to study the Van Allen Belts and to unravel the mystery of their unpredictability.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Radiation Belt Storm Probes

snippet.description: The second full Moon of August--a "Blue Moon"--is just around the corner. It will probably look just like any other full Moon but, on rare occasions, the Moon really does turn blue. Could it happen this month?
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Watch Out For The Blue Moon

snippet.description: Curiosity is safe on Mars and ready to roll. In this video from Science@NASA, project scientist John Grotzinger discusses where the rover might go first.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Where Will Curiosity Go First?

snippet.description: The Perseid meteor shower is underway. There's more to see than meteors, however, when the shower peaks on August 11th through 13th. The brightest planets in the solar system are lining up in the middle of the display.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: 2012 Perseid Meteor Shower

snippet.description: A key ingredient of Earth's strangest clouds does not come from Earth. New data from NASA's AIM spacecraft proves that "meteor smoke" is essential to the formation of noctilucent clouds.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Meteor Smoke Makes Strange Clouds

snippet.description: On the same night Curiosity lands on Mars, a "Martian Triangle" will appear in sunset skies of Earth. The first-magnitude apparition on August 5th gives space fans something to do while they wait for news from the Red Planet.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Mars Landing Sky Show

snippet.description: Solar maximum is still a year away. This month sky watchers got a taste of things to come when a powerful flare sparked Northern Lights over the United States as far south as Arkansas, Colorado and California.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: A Taste of Solar Maximum

snippet.description: More than 8 years after landing on the Red Planet, Mars rover Opportunity is still running. Indeed, mission planners say the tireless robot is poised to complete a full marathon--the first ever long-distance race on an alien planet.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The First Extraterrestrial Marathon

snippet.description: The brightest planets in the solar system are converging for a beautiful sunrise sky show in early July.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: A Good Reason to Wake Up at Dawn

snippet.description: A NASA-sponsored researcher at the University of Iowa has developed a way for spacecraft to hunt down hidden magnetic portals in the vicinity of Earth. These portals link the magnetic field of our planet to that of the sun.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Hidden Magnetic Portals Around Earth

snippet.description:
At the edge of the solar system, Voyager 1 is reporting a sharp increase in cosmic rays that could herald the spacecraft's long-awaited entry into interstellar space.

Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Voyager 1 at the Final Frontier

snippet.description: A question has been troubling astronomers: Why won't the supernova explode? Although real stars blow up, the best computer models of dying stars do not result in much of a bang. NASA has launched a new observatory named "NuSTAR" to seek out the missing physics of exploding stars.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Why Won't the Supernova Explode?

snippet.description: Astronomers no longer have any doubt: Our Milky Way Galaxy will have a head-on collision with Andromeda. Fortunately, they say, Earth will survive when the two great star systems meet 4 billions years from now.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Andromeda vs. the Milky Way: Astronomers Predict a Titanic Collision

snippet.description: High above Earth, astronaut Don Pettit is about to become the first human to witness and photograph a transit of Venus from space. His images and commentary will be streamed to Earth during the crossing.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: ISS Transit of Venus

snippet.description: On Monday, June 4th, the Moon will pass through the shadow of Earth, producing a partial lunar eclipse visible across the Pacific from China to the United States.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Partial Eclipse of the Strawberry Moon

snippet.description: It won't happen again until December 2117. On June 5th, 2012, Venus will transit the face of the sun in an event of both historical and observational importance. The best places to watch are in the south Pacific, but travel is not required. The event will also be visible around sunset from the USA.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The 2012 Transit of Venus

snippet.description: Superficially, Saturn's moon Phoebe doesn't look much like a planet, but on the inside, the little gray moon has a lot in common with worlds like Earth.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Don't Judge a Moon by its Cover

snippet.description: NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory has mapped the debris of a supernova and discovered that the explosion may have turned the original star inside out. Peering into the heart of the inverted star, astronomers have found the atoms of life itself.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: A Star Turns Inside Out

snippet.description:
Amateur scientists have made a effervescent discovery: The Milky Way Galaxy is bubbling like a glass of champagne.

Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Amateur Scientists Discover Galactic Bubbles

snippet.description: Solar storms and Northern Lights are in the offing as the sun approaches Solar Max, expected in mid-to-late 2013. Recently, Earth's defenses were tested by a volley of strong eruptions. Find out what happened in this week's explosive ScienceCast.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Here Comes Solar Maximum

snippet.description:
One year after the historic tornado outbreak of April 27-28, 2011, researchers say they've learned a few things about deadly twisters. This week's ScienceCast presents some of the scientific findings that emerged from the swath of destruction.

Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: April is the Cruelest Month

snippet.description: NASA ScienceCasts SMD "Science Mission Directorate" "Science@NASA News" "Lyrid meteor shower" Mars Saturn "Comet Thatcher" "backyard astronomy" "new Moon"
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: A Wonderful Night in April

snippet.description: NASA's Kepler spacecraft is discovering a veritable avalanche of alien worlds. As the numbers mount, it seems to be just a matter of time before Kepler finds what astronomers are really looking for: an Earth-like planet orbiting its star in the "Goldilocks zone".
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Getting to Know the Goldilocks Planet

snippet.description: A flurry of solar activity in early March dumped enough heat in Earth's upper atmosphere to power every residence in New York City for two years. The heat has since dissipated, but there's more to come as the solar cycle intensifies.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Surprising Power of a Solar Storm

snippet.description: NASA's Fermi Gamma-Ray Telescope is finding hundreds of new objects at the very edge of the electromagnetic spectrum. Many of them have one thing in common: Astronomers have no idea what they are.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Mysterious Objects at the Edge of the Electromagnetic Spectrum

snippet.description: NASA ScienceCasts SMD "Science Mission Directorate" "Science@NASA News" "full Moon" tides perigee "moon myths" "moon illusion" "howling dogs" crime
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Super Moon of May 2012

snippet.description: Lately, the International Space Station has been flying through geomagnetic storms, giving astronauts an close-up view of the aurora borealis just outside their windows.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Auroras Underfoot

snippet.description: En route to the Red Planet, Mars rover Curiosity has experienced the strongest solar radiation storm since 2005. No need to be alarmed: Researchers say it's all part of Curiosity's job as a 'stunt double' for human astronauts.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Curiosity, The Stunt Double

snippet.description: The brightest planets in the night sky are aligning for a must-see show in late February and March 2012. Start looking tonight!
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: An Alignment of Planets

snippet.description:
"Alien matter" detected by a NASA spacecraft orbiting Earth shows that the chemical make-up of our solar system differs from that of the surrounding galaxy. Researchers discuss the possible meaning of this mismatch in this week's ScienceCast video.
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Alien Matter in the Solar System

snippet.description: Europe's Rosetta spacecraft is en route to intercept a comet-- and to make history. In 2014, Rosetta will enter orbit around 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko and land a probe on it for a front row seat as the comet heads toward the sun
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Mission to Land on a Comet

snippet.description:
NASA ScienceCasts SMD "Science Mission Directorate" "Science@NASA News" "La Nina" "El Nino" "solar eclipse" annular "ring of fire" "partial eclipse" "eclipse glasses" "solar filters"
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.
Timetables and maps at http://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/
A "ring of fire" solar eclipse is coming to the USA this spring. It's the first annular eclipse visible from the contiguous United States in almost 18 years.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Solar Eclipse in the USA

snippet.description: Winter seems to have been on hold this year in some parts of the United States. Snowfall has been scarce in places that were overwhelmed with the white stuff at the same time last year. In this ScienceCast, JPL climatologist Bill Patzert explains what's going on.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: What Happened to all the Snow?

snippet.description:
Astronomers are still scratching their heads over Comet Lovejoy, which plunged through the atmosphere of the sun in December and, against all odds, survived. The comet is now receding into the outer solar system leaving many mysteries behind.
Visit http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2012/12jan_cometlovejoy/ for more.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Some Comets Like It Hot

snippet.description: A distant super-Earth named "55 Cancri e" is wetter and weirder than astronomers thought possible. The discovery has researchers re-thinking the nature of alien worlds.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Re-thinking an Alien World

snippet.description:
A new iPhone app just released by NASA harnesses the power of citizen scientists to track space debris around Earth.

Visit http://science.nasa.gov/ for more.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Tracking Meteoroids

snippet.description: NASA's Dawn probe, now orbiting Vesta in the asteroid belt, has found some surprising things on the giant asteroid--things that have prompted one researcher to declare Vesta "the smallest terrestrial planet."
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Smallest Terrestrial Planet?

snippet.description: On Dec 10th, sky watchers in the western United States will witness a total lunar eclipse swollen to super-sized proportions by the Moon illusion.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: A Super-Sized Lunar Eclipse

snippet.description: A distant world is being hit by solar storms so ferocious, the entire planet is probably enveloped in auroras. Researchers speculate that the display is probably as beautiful as it is terrifying.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Terrifying Auroras

snippet.description: Scientists studying data from NASA's Galileo probe have discovered what appears to be a body of liquid water the volume of the North American Great Lakes locked inside the icy shell of Jupiter's moon Europa. This improves the odds that Europa is a habitat for extraterrestrial life.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Great Lakes of Europa

snippet.description: How can a world without air have an ionosphere? Somehow the Moon has done it. Lunar researchers have been struggling with this mystery for years, and they may have finally found a solution.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Mystery of the Lunar Ionosphere

snippet.description: A NASA space telescope named "GALEX" has found stars forming in extreme galactic environments, places where researchers thought stars should not be. The finding could affect astronomy much as the discovery of microbial extremophiles affected biology in the 1970s.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Stellar Extremophiles

snippet.description: Using a Japanese telescope, NASA-supported researchers have found the first clear case of a star with spiral arms.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: A Star with Spiral Arms

snippet.description: NASA's MESSENGER probe has discovered a surprise on Mercury: Something is digging "hollows" in the surface of the innermost planet.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Sleepy Hollows of Mercury

snippet.description: The Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope recently produced a map of the night sky. Out of 1873 new sources, nearly 600 were complete mysteries. In this week's ScienceCast, researchers speculate on the nature of the mystery objects - including the possibility that they are made of dark matter.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: 600 Mysteries in the Night Sky

snippet.description: Forecasters say Earth is heading for a stream of dust from Comet 21P/Giacobini-Zinner. A close encounter with the comet's fragile debris could spark a meteor outburst over parts of our planet on October 8th.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Draconid Meteor Outburst

snippet.description: NASA's newest rover Curiosity is getting ready to leave Earth. It's destination: Gale crater on Mars. Today's story from Science@NASA explains the attraction of this Martian crater with a strangely-sculpted mountain the middle.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: The Strange Attraction of Gale Crater

snippet.description: Did our planet once have two moons? Some researchers say so. Moreover, the missing satellite might still be up there--splattered across the far side of the Moon. NASA's GRAIL mission could help confirm or refute the "two moon" hypothesis.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Did Earth Have Two Moons?

snippet.description: Researchers have just discovered that solar flares have been keeping a secret--and it's a big one.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Secret Lives of Solar Flares

snippet.description: Dwarf planet Pluto is a world of mystery waiting to be visited for the first time. NASA's New Horizons probe is racing across the solar system for a ground breaking close encounter that could dramatically alter what researchers "know" about Pluto and other small worlds.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Visit To Pluto

snippet.description: Stars as cold as the human body? Believe it. A NASA spacecraft has discovered a half-dozen "Y Dwarfs" with atmospheric temperatures as low as 80 F.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Cool Stars

snippet.description: On August 13th, space station astronaut Ron Garan photographed a centimeter-sized chunk of comet debris disintegrating in Earth's atmosphere. His rare photo of a meteor from Earth orbit is a must-see.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Bright Perseid Photographed from Space

snippet.description: The same kind of oxygen humans breath on Earth has been found in deep space. It's a breath of fresh air for astronomers who have been searching for cosmic "O2" until now without success.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Breath of Fresh Air

snippet.description: NASA's Dawn spacecraft doesn't do things like other missions. In July it slipped into orbit around asteroid Vesta using a smooth move that made mission planners want to get up and dance.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Dawn's Smooth Move

snippet.description: For four long centuries the gas giant's vast interior has remained hidden from view. NASA's Juno probe, scheduled to launch on August 5th, could change all that.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: What Lies Inside Jupiter?

snippet.description: On July 5th, a comet dove into the sun and disintegrated.  New footage just released by NASA shows the final stages of the comet's death plunge.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Sun Grazing Comet

snippet.description: If you're camping out and can't sleep, maybe your slumber is being interrupted by the flash of meteors. The summer Perseid meteor shower is getting underway as Earth enters the debris stream from comet Swift-Tuttle.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Summer Meteor Shower

snippet.description: NASA has just released new movies of an "inky-dark" solar explosion that continues to puzzle experts more than a month after it happened.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Dark Fireworks

snippet.description: Stars are bright, but their planets are not, which makes planet hunting difficult. NASA's ultraviolet telescope GALEX may be providing a solution.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: An Astronomer's Dilemma

snippet.description: Record snowfall, killer tornadoes, devastating floods: There's no doubt about it. Since Dec. 2010, the weather in the USA has been positively wild. But why?
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Wild Weather

snippet.description: Aquarius is the first NASA sensor to track ocean salinity from space, and aims to help uncover how the salinity of Earth's oceans are effecting our climate.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Power of Sea Salt

snippet.description: NASA's Voyager probes have reached the edge of the solar system and found something surprising there--a froth of magnetic bubbles separating us from the rest of the galaxy.
snippet.title: ScienceCasts: Big Surprise
